twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: Winter is the WORST time to install hardwood flooring. But 60% of my calls come in December-February. Here's why that's a problem 🧵
thread_structure: Winter is the WORST time to install hardwood flooring. But 60% of my calls come in December-February. Here's why that's a problem 🧵
Wood expands and contracts with humidity. Winter = dry air from heating = wood contracts. Install in winter, it expands in summer.
Result: Buckling, cupping, gaps that appear and disappear. I've seen it destroy $30K installations.
Best time to install hardwood: Spring or Fall when humidity is stable and close to year-round average.
But customers want it done during the holidays when they have time off. I get it. Here's what I do:
1) Run humidifiers during acclimation (7-10 days) 2) Maintain 35-55% humidity during install 3) Leave proper expansion gaps 4) Set expectations
I also charge 15% more for winter installs because of the extra steps and risk. Most contractors don't do this prep and the floor fails.
Planning a flooring project? Think about timing. It matters more than you realize.
